title: 109_hr2936
content: The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" requires group health plans to cover second opinions under the Public Health Service Act. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" mandates group health plans to provide or authorize second opinions by qualified healthcare professionals upon request from participants, beneficiaries, or enrollees questioning surgical procedures or diagnoses that pose a threat to life or bodily functions. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" requires group health plans to offer second opinions for unclear diagnoses, ineffective treatments, or when requested by participants concerned about life-threatening conditions or serious impairments. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" mandates group health plans to provide second opinions when enrollees have serious concerns about their diagnosis or treatment. An appropriately qualified health care professional, such as a primary care physician or specialist, must offer timely opinions related to the specific illness or condition in question. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" requires group health plans to provide timely second opinions upon request, especially in cases of imminent health threats. Opinions must be rendered within 72 hours of the plan's receipt of the request. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" mandates group health plans to provide timely second opinions within 72 hours of receiving a request. Plans must also establish timelines for responding to requests for second opinions within 90 days of the enactment of the act. Participants are only responsible for copayments if a second opinion is approved. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" requires group health plans to provide timely second opinions. Participants can choose their healthcare professional for second opinions, with the plan covering the cost beyond copayments. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" mandates group health plans to offer timely second opinions. If no participating provider meets the required standard, the plan must authorize a second opinion from a qualified health professional outside the network. The plan covers the cost of the second opinion, but not the travel expenses. The plan or issuer must ensure a second opinion health professional provides a consultation report to the participant, beneficiary, or enrollee and the initial health professional. If the plan denies a request for a second opinion, written notice must be given to the participant, beneficiary, or enrollee. The plan must notify the participant of denial reasons for a second opinion and their right to file a grievance. Services must be obtained from participating providers unless authorized by the plan. The section does not apply to certain health care service plan contracts. The section exempts health care service plan contracts under preferred provider arrangements if access to second opinions is not limited. Group health plans must comply with notice requirements similar to ERISA regulations. Amendments include adding section 2707 to ERISA. ERISA amendments include adding section 2707 to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. "SEC. 714. COVERAGE OF SECOND OPINIONS." Section 2707 applies to group health plans and insurance coverage. The requirement is considered a material modification in the plan, with notice required within 60 days. Section 731(c) of the Act is amended to include sections 711 and 714. Section 731(c) of the Act (29 U.S.C. 1191(c)) is amended to include sections 711 and 714, along with other related amendments to the Act. Coverage of second opinions is added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 under section 9813. Coverage of second opinions is included in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 under section 9813, with requirements similar to those in the Public Health Service Act. In the individual market, health insurance coverage must comply with section 2707 provisions. Health insurance issuers must also provide notice as required by the Employee Retirement Income Security Act. Section 2762(b)(2) of the Act is amended to include additional sections. Effective dates apply to group health plans and insurance. Effective dates for the amendments made by subsections (a) and (b) apply to group health plans starting on or after January 1, 2006, and to individual health insurance coverage offered on or after that date. There is an exception for group health plans under collective bargaining agreements ratified before the enactment of the Act. The amendments made by subsections (a) and (b) do not apply to plan years beginning before the later of the date on which the last collective bargaining agreements relating to the plan terminates or January 1, 2006. Plan amendments made to conform to new requirements shall not be considered a termination of the collective bargaining agreement. Coordination of administration is handled by the Secretary of Labor, Treasury, and Health and Human Services. The Secretary of Labor, Treasury, and Health and Human Services must coordinate administration to ensure regulations are consistent and enforcement efforts are coordinated to avoid duplication.
